fields.headline: Collision
fields.bodyText: So it was the wasp wot dunnit. Caused the death of six people, three of them murdered. And caused a multi-millionaire to fall in love with a service station waitress, but not have the courage to leave his wife; plus two police officers who used to have a thing together get their thing together back again. Powerful little things, aren't they? I should have known – one flew into my crash helmet the other day. I just managed to stop and pull it off before I caused my own pile-up with multiple fatalities and the inevitable subsequent unearthing of large-scale corporate wrong-doing, people-smuggling, murder and the like. And we did, in fact, see it – the wasp – in the first episode, at the service station. The pretty waitress tried to take her frustration at having a rubbish boyfriend out on the wasp by swatting it, but she missed. So then it buzzed off, chased a car travelling at 70 miles an hour, flew in through the window, upset the paedophile piano teacher, who turned out not to be a paedophile but a trekkie, and made him cause a horrendous crash with multiple vehicles, multiple fatalities and multiple repercussions. It wasn't just the piano teacher I was wrong about. The antiques dealer wasn't bringing drugs over from Holland in a secret compartment in his van, but Africans. Fitting then, that he should end up in a car crusher himself. Collision was intriguing and gripping and ambitious and a bit daft, all at the same time. There was so much going on, so much build-up, that it couldn't help leaving you feeling empty at the end, falling a bit flat. The wasp thing was just a bit irritating. But not quite as annoying as the alternative ending – the one where the waitress got the wasp after all. So it didn't then go and bother the trekkie-not-paedo piano teacher, so he didn't swerve, the accident never happened, none of the murders took place, the Africans arrived safely, and the cops never re-copped off with each other. Did it happen, or not? Or are we now meant to go and ponder the randomness of chance or fate or something? Hmmm.
